info.document:
The city came in at number 10 on the list, but was beaten by Oxford in at number five

Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email

Cambridge has fallen behind Oxford in a list of the happiest places to live in the UK, according to a new survey.

The city came in at number 10 on the list, but was beaten by Oxford in at number five.

The popular coastal city of Brighton beat competition from Leicester and Portsmouth to take the top spot.

Norwich and Bristol also appeared in the top ten happiest cities to live in, while Manchester, Belfast and Cardiff all took high positions.

In terms of cities for life satisfaction, Cambridge ranked almost bottom of the list at number 21 out of 23. Oxford was number one, with Bristol at number two and Brighton and Hove coming in third.

Cambridge has also fared pretty poorly in other aspects - it was voted the worst city for travelling in and out of , and also the most unequal city in the UK .

But Cambridge has ranked highly in other surveys - residents in Cambridge were voted to have the third sexiest accent in England last month.

In response to the survey Emma Thornton, chief executive of Visit Cambridge, set up to promote and encourage tourism in the city, said: "Cambridge is a great place to live and visit because it is a city which has so much to offer.

"There's beautiful architecture steeped in history, a fantastic and rich arts and cultural scene, great shopping and choice of restaurants with beautiful open green spaces.

"As well as all of that, the river is only minutes' walk from all the hustle and bustle."

The study, commissioned by the 9NINE Super Seed brand, asked 3,000 Brits to consider their general life satisfaction and rate how they feel on a scale of one to ten.

Oxford came top in the life satisfaction stakes with a score of 6.72 out of ten, while Edinburgh found itself at the bottom of the table with a life satisfaction average of 5.89 out of ten.

Marketing Director Kerry Collinge, for 9NINE Super Seed brand, said: "Brighton residents have found themselves topping our happiest city chart.

Old Cambridge picture quiz View gallery

Old Cambridge picture quiz

View gallery

"Maybe it's the sea air and sunny weather that keeps them smiling."

When asked to rate their life satisfaction on a scale from one to ten, the average Brit gave themselves a middling 6.37 out of ten.

Just one in ten rated their life satisfaction at nine or above, indicating excellent life satisfaction.

Researchers also looked into the ways we boost our mood - and found three in five look to bed for comfort in hard times, and over half lean on family for support.

Forty three per cent play their favourite music when they need to raise their spirits, with reading a book proving more popular for boosting our serotonin levels than sex.

But it's the typical British weather which is most likely to get us feeling down in the dumps first place, with 40 per cent claiming inclement weather has a negative effect on their emotions.

It also emerged the average Brit believes they will be at their happiest at the age of 33, with just over a third think their best years are now behind them.

But an optimistic fifth think they are currently having the time of their lives.

The happiest cities in the UK

1. Brighton and Hove

2. Leicester

3. Portsmouth

4. Newcastle

5. Oxford

6. Chelmsford

7. Norwich

8. Bristol

9. London

10. Cambridge

11. Manchester

12. Belfast

13. Coventry

14. Cardiff

15. Birmingham

16. York

17. Plymouth

18. Sheffield

19. Leeds

20. Glasgow

21. Southampton

22. Liverpool

23. Edinburgh

You can keep up to date with all the latest news in and around Cambridge by downloading our free app. It is available for the iPhone and iPad from Apple's App Store , or the Android version can be downloaded from Google Play .
